awd_titl_txt: Homological Aspects of Exterior and Other Power Operations
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research into one of the fundamental questions of algebraic geometry: How does one find measures of a singularity? A singularity is a place on a curve, surface, or higher dimensional space where it is not smooth, that is, it has a cusp (a sharp point, a place where it folds or turns abruptly) or it crosses itself. The understanding of singularities has applications to computer vision and medical imaging. In general, one wants to find and study measures of how extreme a singularity is and how these vary under operations such as deformations. This is done using abstract algebraic techniques as usually the dimension, or the number of equations, or variable and unknown coefficients make the spaces completely impractical to visualize. The goal is to attach invariants to singularities that are measures of the nature of the singularity. This project studies such invariants in three different ways. 

More precisely, this project involves the study of the exterior algebra, modules of higher differentials, exterior powers of complexes, and related power operations such as Adams operations, sometimes with differential graded algebra structures playing a role. The homological behavior of exterior power operations is known to be complicated, yet these algebras and operations play a central role throughout many parts of algebra and mathematics. This project focuses on the following research directions (1) Adams operations and applications to Hilbert-Kunz multiplicities, (2) invariants of singularities for p-differentials, and (3) resolutions of graded Artinian algebras. For the first, the main goal is to develop a characteristic zero version of Hilbert-Kunz multiplicity. For the second, the focus is on studying singularities via their modules of higher differentials; the goal is to understand symmetries and the vanishing of invariants obtained from them, such as generalized Tjurina numbers, by showing how their resolutions are interrelated in the general non-isolated Gorenstein singularity setting. The third involves applying the resolution of Artinian algebras to various problems, such as conjectures on Betti numbers and finding dg-structures on resolutions in order to further understand Koszul homology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: 

Differentials, as well as derivations and higher order differential operators, are fundamental invariants of a singularity, or non-smooth point, in an algebraic curve, surface, or higher dimensional space studied in the field of algebraic geometry. Studied for more than half a century by ring theory or sheaf cohomology, the PI's approach has been to use homological algebra techniques instead. In this wide set of related projects, the PI has made progress on the free resolutions of several of these modules and relations to the cotangent complex. 

In a major subproject, the PI determined the differential operators of order three for cones of a smooth projective plane curves in characteristic zero. Although studied for singularities for at least fifty years, little concrete was known via algebro-geometric methods. Differential operators are difficult to determine and partial progress is interesting, especially as some structural stability with increasing order is becoming visible. 

In the another direction, differential graded (dg) algebra structures are a fundamental tool for understanding singularities. Introduced into commutative algebra as a method for establishing the Buchsbaum-Eisenbud-Horrocks conjecture, but have expanded to be a major focus of study. The PI has contributed to the field in two ways. 

First, the PI developed a method for transferring such structures from one complex to another. This enables one to use known structures on canonical resolutions and move them to minimal resolutions. More generally, the PI's transfer results could be useful to researchers in algebraic topology as they are a type of Homotopy Transfer Theorem. We were invited by an editor to submit it for publication in a topology journal. Our result has also been used by the algebra community in a different setting. 

The PI then applied this method to find a new way to obtain such structures on the minimal free resolutions of powers of the homogeneous maximal ideal in the polynomial ring, with an eventual goal of building them on almost all such resolutions. Even partial progress is effective: These dg-algebra structures have an impact on many parts of commutative algebra as they would explain why some results seem to hold most of the time. 

Second, the PI then extended the ideas of that project to construct the minimal free resolutions of powers of the homogeneous maximal ideal for a class of much-studied rings, namely Koszul algebras, although not dg algebra structures. Ideas related to this work have also enabled the PI to make progress on the building dg algebra structures much more generally. 

The PI also used dg algebra structures to obtain the Hilbert-Kunz function of certain, that is, very general, graded hypersurfaces in 3 variables. 

In another direction, the PI has obtained an explicit isomorphism between Iyengar's bar resolutions and the well-known Eagon resolutions, explaining how such different structures are related. The project involves extending the construction of Massey operations to a broader setting. 

Lastly, the PI has worked on constructing and applying Adams operations to various settings, with less progress to report here. During the grant, the PI has developed these for n-fold matrix factorizations that should have applications to the study of certain fundamental invariants for those. 

Altogether, these are joint work with Rahmati, Diethorn, Jeffries, Packauskas, Pollitz, Rahmati, Vassilliadou, Faber, Lindo, Juhnke-Kubitzke, R.G., Seceleanu, Briggs, Yang, and Walker.

 

Broader impacts: 

The PI mentored 5 graduate students, all of whom finished during the tenure of the grant; three of these are female. 

The PI was project co-leader for one of the research groups at the WICA (Women in Commutative Algebra) workshop at Banff in October.

The PI co-edited the (refereed) proceedings volume in the Springer AWM Series for the WICA workshop.

The PI participated in the MSRI Women's summer program.

The PI gave a week-long lecture series with problem sessions at PASCA, which was run this summer at CIMAT in Mexico for 40 students, half each from the US and Mexico. The lectures will be typed up and published. 

The PI applied to run a MSRI summer graduate school in China, which was approved, but postponed due to the pandemic until a convenient time.

The PI co-organized 2 workshops at ICERM. 

The PI co-organized experimental virtual workshops at the Fields Institute, Women in Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry, to create a small community of women researchers to work on problems in small groups. The first group is collaborating successfully and the second workshop is upcoming.

Together with an algebraist and two topologists, the PI is co-organizing a BIRS workshop on long-open set of problems sitting across the fields of homological commutative algebra and algebraic topology, for this September. This summer, the we held a virtual reading seminar to prepare the participants at the student or postdoctoral level. 

The PI co-organizes of the virtual Fellowship of the Ring, a national Commutative Algebra seminar, begun during the pandemic.
